Expectation1: Ensure compliance with tax laws and regulations.
Situation1: A seminar is being offered on potential tax law changes that may occur in the next few years.
Expectation2: Officiate at life cycle events such as weddings, bar/bat mitzvahs, and funerals.
Situation2: A couple has made an initial inquiry about his availability for a wedding over a year away.
Story: I stared at the email from the accounting firm, inviting me to a seminar on upcoming tax law changes. As an accountant, I knew how crucial it was to stay ahead of new regulations—my clients depended on me to keep them compliant and avoid costly mistakes. The seminar was scheduled for a weekend next year, and I quickly checked my calendar. That’s when I saw the note: “Wedding inquiry—Sarah & Ben, same weekend.” As their rabbi, I was their first choice to officiate, and I knew how much it would mean to them if I could be there. My mind raced with the expectations on both sides. My accounting clients needed my expertise, and missing the seminar could put me behind. But as a rabbi, I was entrusted with guiding people through their most significant moments. I felt the weight of both roles pressing in, each demanding my presence, each unwilling to yield. I sat at my desk, torn, the cursor blinking on my screen, waiting for me to respond.
